Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Soil Improvement Through Bio-Cementation: Physical and Numerical Experiments

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dynamic loading associated with earthquake shaking can lead to the liquefaction of loose, saturated sands, essentially transforming competent geological material into quicksand. Any structures - natural or man-made - that exist on these deposits will suffer catastrophic damage due to the loss of strength associated with liquefaction. Cemented soils, however, are less prone to liquefaction than loose granular materials. Cementation can occur naturally due to the precipitation of certain minerals or may be induced via chemical injections. More recently, novel biological techniques such as microbially induced calcite precipitation (MICP) have been used in the laboratory to mimic the natural cementation process. The biological cementation techniques have the potential to be more sustainable than traditional chemical injection methods. This work will explore the effects of bio-cementation using a tightly integrated numerical-experimental program. The expected outcome of the work is a modeling framework: if the level of cementation is known, then bio-cemented soil behavior can be predicted. Thus, the models dveloped as part of this work will help engineers use bio-cementation to prevent liquefaction during future earthquakes. The work will be broadly disseminated through course development and a collaboration with the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry.

Bio-cementation such as MICP has the potential to increase liquefaction resistance by increasing the cyclic strength of sand, reducing the generated excess pore pressures, and reducing settlements due to dynamic loading. The behavior of cemented soil is extremely dependent on the mineralogy of the cementing agent. Sands cemented artificially with chemical agents, such as lime, ordinary Portland cement, and gypsum behave differently than naturally cemented soils. Thus, existing models used to simulate the behavior of chemically-cemented sand are not appropriate for bio-cemented sand. Before implementing MICP for liquefaction mitigation, a better understanding of the underlying physics governing the constitutive behavior of bio-cemented sands is necessary. Measuring the underlying micromechanics (e.g., changes in particle roughness, calcite fines generation during shearing) is difficult with traditional experiments, so discrete element method simulations will be used to help study bio-cemented sand at the microscale. Element- and particle scale behavior of bio-cemented sands will be assessed through a combination of strength testing, particle-scale measurements, and X-ray computed tomography. Results from these experiments will be used to develop and calibrate numerical models to predict the bulk response of bio-cemented sands subjected to static and dynamic loading.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many geotechnical engineering projects encounter liquefiable soils where improvement of the ground is required before application of structural load to the bearing soil. A typical approach to soil improvement in such a situation would be to stabilize the soil using a cementitious compound. However, the manufacture of synthetic cement has a large carbon footprint – it is the source of approximately 8% of the world’s CO2 emissions. There is thus significant motivation to develop more carbon-neutral means of generating cementitious compounds for a variety of uses, not just soil improvement. These are the broader impacts of this work.

Recently, biological processes have received increasing interest as a potential method for altering the properties of soils in-situ. More specifically, Sporosarcina pasteurii, an aerobic bacterium with a high metabolic activity, has been used widely for improving engineering properties of soils at the lab scale. Sporosarcina pasteurii uses urea as an energy source and produces ammonia which increases the pH in the proximal environment. Ammonia in the presence of calcium precipitates as calcite on grain surfaces and grain contact points. The precipitated calcite at contact points bonds the grains together and increases the contact area while that on grain surfaces increases particle surface roughness.

Over the last decade, numerous experimental studies have been performed to determine if the degree of improvement caused by bio-cementation would satisfy the geotechnical requirements that are demanded by construction projects. Results show that bio-cementation increases the shear strength, stiffness, and volume change behavior of soil. An increase in liquefaction resistance and reduction of settlement due to dynamic loading have also been observed. Some studies have revealed that the mechanical behavior of bio-cemented sand is not just a function of mass of calcite but also the distribution of calcite

In this work, the knowledge provided by experiments about the formation, distribution, and microstructure of calcite bonds is used as a basis for numerical modeling of the mechanical behavior of bio-cemented sand. This is the intellectual merit of the work. The discrete element method (DEM) has been widely used for modeling of bonded granular materials and is employed herein.

As part of this project, we simulate the stress-strain-volume change behavior of bio-cemented sand based on the current understanding of calcite bond micro-structure that has been achieved through experiments. The developed model considers: (1) the granular structure of calcite bonds; (2) generation of free calcite grains after bond failure; and (3) the increase of host soil surface friction due to the fact that the host particles are coated with calcite. Results of DEM simulations closely match test results from physical experiments. After verification, the numerical model was used to investigate the effect of the presence and breakage of calcite bonds on the microscale behavior of bio-cemented sand, elucidating the fundamental differences between bio-mediated cementation and other types of soil bonding.
